channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Los Angeles celebrates the Dodgers' back-to-back World Series championship
item.description: The Dodgers are the first repeat World Series champions since 2000 when the New York Yankees won three in a row. Already, people in Los Angeles are looking ahead to next season to equal the feat.
item.content:encoded:
The Dodgers are the first repeat World Series champions since 2000 when the New York Yankees won three in a row. Already, people in Los Angeles are looking ahead to next season to equal the feat.

(Image credit: Jae C. Hong)
item.dc:creator: Steve Futterman

item.title: Dilbert creator taps Trump to get cancer drug. Others wish they could, too
item.description: Like many Americans, Scott Adams had insurance problems. But unlike most people he has powerful friends on social media, and when he asked President Trump for help, he got the cancer drug he needed.
item.content:encoded:
Like many Americans, Scott Adams had insurance problems. But unlike most people he has powerful friends on social media, and when he asked President Trump for help, he got the cancer drug he needed.

(Image credit: Marcio Jose Sanchez)
item.dc:creator: Yuki Noguchi

item.title: A gun violence 'action plan' calls for a new emphasis on prevention
item.description: Dozens of leaders in medicine, criminal justice and more issued an urgent call for collective action to tackle the gun violence crisis in the U.S.
item.content:encoded:
Dozens of leaders in medicine, criminal justice and more issued an urgent call for collective action to tackle the gun violence crisis in the U.S.

(Image credit: Jeff Wheeler/Star Tribune)
item.dc:creator: Rhitu Chatterjee

item.title: Tanzanian opposition decries 'sham' elections, alleges hundreds of deaths
item.description: Tanzanian President Samia Suluhu Hassan sworn in for a second term amid disputed 98% win, deadly protests, and an information blackout.
item.content:encoded:
Tanzanian President Samia Suluhu Hassan sworn in for a second term amid disputed 98% win, deadly protests, and an information blackout.

(Image credit: str)
item.dc:creator: Kate Bartlett

item.title: SNAP benefits will restart, but will be half the normal payment and delayed
item.description: About 1 in 8 U.S. residents get an average of $187 a month per person in the food assistance known as SNAP. For the first time, the Trump administration stopped the payments due at the beginning of the month.
item.content:encoded:
About 1 in 8 U.S. residents get an average of $187 a month per person in the food assistance known as SNAP. For the first time, the Trump administration stopped the payments due at the beginning of the month.

(Image credit: Hart Van Denburg)
item.dc:creator: Maria Godoy

item.title: Public workers could be denied loan forgiveness if cities defy Trump, lawsuit alleges
item.description: A new lawsuit argues the latest changes to Public Service Loan Forgiveness could exclude public servants whose organizations have resisted President Trump's policies.
item.content:encoded:
A new lawsuit argues the latest changes to Public Service Loan Forgiveness could exclude public servants whose organizations have resisted President Trump's policies.

(Image credit: Josh Lawton)
item.dc:creator: Cory Turner

item.title: Huggies maker Kimberly-Clark is buying Tylenol maker Kenvue
item.description: One of the biggest mergers of the year, worth $49 billion, comes just weeks after the Trump administration linked the common painkiller to autism, which the company is fighting.
item.content:encoded:
One of the biggest mergers of the year, worth $49 billion, comes just weeks after the Trump administration linked the common painkiller to autism, which the company is fighting.

(Image credit: Scott Olson)
item.dc:creator: Alina Selyukh

item.title: Nearly 400,000 people are starving in Sudan, a new report finds
item.description: The war involving the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces has created the world's largest humanitarian disaster, a leading hunger agency says. The major city of el-Fasher has been particularly hard-hit.
item.content:encoded:
The war involving the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces has created the world's largest humanitarian disaster, a leading hunger agency says. The major city of el-Fasher has been particularly hard-hit.

(Image credit: Marwan Mohammed)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Judge says Trump administration must fund SNAP. And, what to know about NYC's election
item.description: Two judges have ordered the Trump administration to fund SNAP benefits. And, New York City voters head to the polls tomorrow to choose between Zohran Mamdani and former Gov. Andrew Cuomo in the mayoral race.
item.content:encoded:
Two judges have ordered the Trump administration to fund SNAP benefits. And, New York City voters head to the polls tomorrow to choose between Zohran Mamdani and former Gov. Andrew Cuomo in the mayoral race.

(Image credit: Aaron Schwartz)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Rigid gender roles are prompting women to leave rural Japan
item.description: Akita Prefecture has Japan's most aged population, lowest birthrate and fastest declining population. Rigid gender roles are prompting young women to leave rural areas like this for opportunities elsewhere.
item.content:encoded: Akita Prefecture has Japan's most aged population, lowest birthrate and fastest declining population. Rigid gender roles are prompting young women to leave rural areas like this for opportunities elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Kuhn
